page.title: 02E.Horsley S. Forestry
page.content: Until 1962 the woods were privately owned, but the land has now been div_ ided into several holdings which are managed by Economic Forestry, in re_ turn for which the owner receives Gov_ ernment Grant Aid. Most of the area is now stocked woodland, 66% broad- leaved & mixed, & 34% conifer forest. The plantings of the early 1960s have now reached the thinning stage & are ready for harvesting. Many varieties of trees were sown but the most succ_ essful have been Corsican pines, Jap_ anese & European larch, Western red cedar, Sitka spruce, Douglas fir & beech. The natural trees are beech, ash, birch, some oak, cherry,sycamore, yew and holly. The most serious threat to all these trees is damage from deer, grey squirrels & voles, necessitating in particular, intensive squirrel control.
